keyTakeAways: Oklahoma’s new superintendent, Lindel Fields, rescinded a mandate from his predecessor, Ryan Walters, that required Bibles to be placed in classrooms and incorporated into lesson plans for students in grades 5 through 12.

The Bible mandate, introduced by former Superintendent Ryan Walters, faced immediate opposition from civil rights groups and a pending lawsuit from parents, teachers, and religious leaders, currently before the Oklahoma Supreme Court.
Fields stated he has no plans to distribute Bibles or a Biblical character education curriculum and believes classroom instruction on religion should be left to individual school districts.
Oklahoma Gov. Kevin Stitt appointed Fields to the superintendent’s role after Walters resigned to take a position in the private sector.

The state education department plans to review all of Ryan Walters’ education mandates, including a requirement for California and New York teacher applicants to pass an 'ideology exam,' to determine if they should be rescinded.
Attorneys representing plaintiffs in the lawsuit welcomed Fields’ decision as a significant step toward ending religious promotion in public education.
Many school districts across Oklahoma had already refused to comply with the Bible mandate, indicating widespread resistance to the policy.
Ryan Walters, a far-right Republican, framed his education policies around combating 'woke ideology' and promoting conspiracy theories related to the 2020 presidential election.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In October 2025, Oklahoma’s new public schools superintendent, Lindel Fields, rescinded a controversial mandate introduced by former Superintendent Ryan Walters that required Bibles to be placed in classrooms and incorporated into student lesson plans for grades 5–12. The policy, which drew immediate backlash from civil rights groups and a pending lawsuit from parents, teachers, and religious leaders, was criticized as a violation of the separation of church and state. Fields emphasized that classroom religious instruction should be left to individual districts and that taxpayer money should not be spent on Bibles. He also stated that the department will review all of Walters’ education mandates, including a requirement for teacher applicants from California and New York to pass an ideology exam, potentially rescinding those as well. The decision signals a reversal of the far-right educational policies under Walters, which included promoting anti-woke ideology and conspiracy theories related to the 2020 presidential election.
title: New Oklahoma Schools Superintendent Rescinds Mandate for Bible Instruction in Schools
